Knowledge Point: Locative clauses are indicated with the \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be, be at (be located at)’ (\sectref{sec:4.3}). The verb p- ‘be’ may be used to express \isi{location} at a place, whether permanent or temporary. The \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be’ can follow either proper \isi{place name}s \REF{ex:pred:1} or \isi{common noun} \isi{location}s \REF{ex:pred:2}.
Content 1: \gsrc Tumbuna la mbïpe \textbf{Wopata pe} ala ando. | \gll tumbuna ala mbï-p-e \textbf{Wopata} \textbf{p-e} ala anda=u | \gls grandparent PL.DIST here-be-DEP [place] be-DEP PL.DIST SG.DIST=from | \glt `When the grandparents were here at Wopata they [went] from there.’
Content 2: \gsrc Alum ala ndï wa lolop ala \textbf{wandam pe} mundu ame. | \gll alum ala ndï wa lolop ala \textbf{wandam} \textbf{p-e} mundu ama-e | \gls child PL.DIST 3PL just just PL.DIST jungle be-DEP food eat-IPFV | \glt `Those children -- they just, they’re just in the jungle eating food.’

Knowledge Point: This verb is irregular in both form and function. First, it is \isi{defective} in that it lacks a \isi{perfective} form.\footnote{This is perhaps unsurprising, given both the \isi{semantic} properties of the verb and the fact that a \isi{perfective} form like \textsuperscript{†}/pp/ very well might just \isi{degeminate} to [p] anyway. On the other hand, \isi{double perfective} forms such as [p-ap], [p-op], and [p-ïp], manage to solve this problem by means of \isi{vowel} insertion (\sectref{sec:4.8}).} Also, given the function of the verb -- often used along with other, non-\isi{locative verb}s -- it is often difficult to interpret the ending [-e] as being either \isi{imperfective} marking or \is{dependent marker} dependent marking. The \isi{irrealis} form of the verb, however, is rather simple to analyze: it takes the form [pïna] -- that is, the \isi{stem} p- ‘be’ plus the regular \isi{irrealis} \isi{suffix} -na ‘\textsc{irr}’, with an \isi{epenthetic} [ï] to break up the underlying \isi{consonant cluster}. The forms of p- ‘be’ are given in \REF{ex:pred:2a}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The un\isi{inflect}ed form [p] may refer either to \isi{past} \isi{time} or to \isi{present} \isi{time}. With reference to \isi{location} in the \isi{future}, however, the \isi{locative verb}, as other verbs, typically receives the \isi{irrealis} \isi{suffix} -na ‘\textsc{irr}’ \REF{ex:pred:3}.
Content 1: \gsrc Uta nungol kwa \textbf{wandam pïna}. | \gll uta nungol kwa \textbf{wandam} \textbf{p-na} | \gls bird child one jungle be-IRR | \glt `[Not] one little bird will be [left] in the jungle!’

Knowledge Point: As with other verbs, the \isi{irrealis} \isi{suffix} encodes not only \isi{future} \isi{time} for the verb p- ‘be’, but also other non-real \isi{modal}ities, such as \isi{counterfactual}s \REF{ex:pred:4}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ango kwe kuma wa \textbf{mapïna}. | \gll ango kwe kuma wa ma=\textbf{p-na} | \gls NEG one some just 3SG.OBJ=be-IRR | \glt `Not just one or a few would be staying there.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:pred:4} further illustrates how the \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be’ can be indexed with \isi{proclitic} \isi{object marker}s or \isi{deictic} forms. In some instances, it may perhaps even be considered a \isi{transitive} verb, taking as its object the place at which something is or was located. In such situations, the verb can be translated as ‘be located at’, ‘stay at’, ‘live at’, ‘reside at’, and so on. This function is illustrated by sentences \REF{ex:pred:5} through \REF{ex:pred:12}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ango kwe kuma wa \textbf{mapïna}. | \gll ango kwe kuma wa ma=\textbf{p-na} | \gls NEG one some just 3SG.OBJ=be-IRR | \glt `Not just one or a few would be staying there.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mï \textbf{wa mape}. | \gll mï \textbf{wa} \textbf{ma=p}-e | \gls 3SG.SUBJ village 3SG.OBJ=be-IPFV | \glt `She stayed in the village.’
Content 3: \gsrc Ase itom ala mïka \textbf{apa ndape}. | \gll ase itom ala mïka \textbf{apa} \textbf{anda=p}-e | \gls no father PL.DIST thus house SG.DIST=be-IPFV | \glt `No, the fathers are in the house.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be’ can take other verbal \isi{affix}ation, such as the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’, as exemplified in examples \REF{ex:pred:1} and \REF{ex:pred:2}. Examples \REF{ex:pred:13} and \REF{ex:pred:14} show p- ‘be’ with the \isi{conditional} marker -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’.
Content 1: \gsrc Tumbuna la mbïpe \textbf{Wopata pe} ala ando. | \gll tumbuna ala mbï-p-e \textbf{Wopata} \textbf{p-e} ala anda=u | \gls grandparent PL.DIST here-be-DEP [place] be-DEP PL.DIST SG.DIST=from | \glt `When the grandparents were here at Wopata they [went] from there.’
Content 2: \gsrc Alum ala ndï wa lolop ala \textbf{wandam pe} mundu ame. | \gll alum ala ndï wa lolop ala \textbf{wandam} \textbf{p-e} mundu ama-e | \gls child PL.DIST 3PL just just PL.DIST jungle be-DEP food eat-IPFV | \glt `Those children -- they just, they’re just in the jungle eating food.’
Content 3: \gsrc Ndï wa \textbf{pïta} | \gll ndï wa p-\textbf{ta} | \gls 3PL village be-COND | \glt `If they were home …’
Content 4: \gsrc … maka amba \textbf{ngapta} ndïlanda man. | \gll maka amba nga=p-\textbf{ta} ndï=la-nda ma-n | \gls thus mens.house SG.PROX=be-COND 3PL=eat-IRR go-IPFV | \glt `… if [we] stay like this in the men’s house, then [we] are going to eat them.’

Knowledge Point: It is also possible for p- ‘be’ to take the \isi{nominalizing} \isi{suffix} -en ‘\textsc{nmlz}’. The force of the \isi{nominalization} is not always felt \REF{ex:pred:15}.
Content 1: \gsrc A nïplopa im in pe wandam \textbf{pen}. | \gll a nïplopa im in p-e wandam p-\textbf{en} | \gls INTERJ flying.fox tree in be-DEP jungle be-NMLZ | \glt `Ah, there are [still] flying foxes in the trees in the jungle.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:pred:15} further illustrates the use of the \isi{locative verb} in combination with a \isi{postpositional phrase} (here, with the \isi{postposition} in ‘in’). Further examples of \isi{locative predication} with \isi{spatial postposition}s are given in \REF{ex:pred:16}, \REF{ex:pred:17}, and \REF{ex:pred:18}.
Content 1: \gsrc A nïplopa im in pe wandam \textbf{pen}. | \gll a nïplopa im in p-e wandam p-\textbf{en} | \gls INTERJ flying.fox tree in be-DEP jungle be-NMLZ | \glt `Ah, there are [still] flying foxes in the trees in the jungle.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nïtet nïmal \textbf{kanam mapen} ndï manji wo. | \gll Nïtet nïmal \textbf{kanam} \textbf{ma=p}-en ndï ma-nji wo | \gls [place] river beside 3SG.OBJ=be-NMLZ 3PL 3SG.OBJ-POSS own | \glt `Those [palms] that are next to Nïtet river are her very own.’\footnote{This example additionally illustrates the use of the \isi{nominalizing} \isi{suffix} -en ‘NMLZ’.} [ulwa037_42:24]’
Content 3: \gsrc Way mï minïn twa \textbf{kana map}. | \gll way mï min=n twa \textbf{kana} \textbf{ma=p} | \gls turtle 3SG.SUBJ 3DU=OBL hearth beside 3SG.OBJ=be | \glt `The turtle stayed there with them next to the hearth.’\footnote{Sentences such as \REF{ex:pred:16} and \REF{ex:pred:17}, which contain the \isi{object marker} ma= ‘3SG.OBJ’
Content 4: \gsrc Nï ango unul ini \textbf{ngawat pïna}. | \gll nï ango un=ul ini nga=\textbf{wat} \textbf{p-}na | \gls 1SG NEG 2PL=with ground this.SG=atop be-IRR | \glt `I will not live on this land with you.’

Knowledge Point: \glt `The turtle stayed there with them next to the hearth.’\footnote{Sentences such as \REF{ex:pred:16} and \REF{ex:pred:17}, which contain the \isi{object marker} ma= ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’ following the \isi{postposition} \textit{kana {\textasciitilde} kanam} ‘beside’, are perhaps better translated as ‘there beside …’ or ‘there next to …’.} [ulwa006_06:09]
Content 1: \gsrc Nïtet nïmal \textbf{kanam mapen} ndï manji wo. | \gll Nïtet nïmal \textbf{kanam} \textbf{ma=p}-en ndï ma-nji wo | \gls [place] river beside 3SG.OBJ=be-NMLZ 3PL 3SG.OBJ-POSS own | \glt `Those [palms] that are next to Nïtet river are her very own.’\footnote{This example additionally illustrates the use of the \isi{nominalizing} \isi{suffix} -en ‘NMLZ’.} [ulwa037_42:24]’
Content 2: \gsrc Way mï minïn twa \textbf{kana map}. | \gll way mï min=n twa \textbf{kana} \textbf{ma=p} | \gls turtle 3SG.SUBJ 3DU=OBL hearth beside 3SG.OBJ=be | \glt `The turtle stayed there with them next to the hearth.’\footnote{Sentences such as \REF{ex:pred:16} and \REF{ex:pred:17}, which contain the \isi{object marker} ma= ‘3SG.OBJ’

Knowledge Point: The distinction between \isi{locative predication} and \isi{existential predication} is often not clear in Ulwa, since there are no formal distinctions between the two constructions. Like \isi{locative predication}, \isi{existential predication} can be expressed with the \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be’, as in \REF{ex:pred:19}, \REF{ex:pred:20}, and \REF{ex:pred:21}.
Content 1: \gsrc Anmoka ndï wandam \textbf{map} | \gll anmoka ndï wandam ma=\textbf{p} | \gls snake 3PL jungle 3SG.OBJ=be | \glt `There are snakes in the jungle.’
Content 2: \gsrc Inim mï ini mawat \textbf{pe}. | \gll inim mï ini ma=wat \textbf{p}-e | \gls water 3SG.SUBJ ground 3SG.OBJ=atop be{-ipfv} | \glt `There is water on the ground.’
Content 3: \gsrc Wanmbi ani \textbf{mapta} u mat nïnata nï ansi lan. | \gll wanmbi ani ma=\textbf{p}-ta u ma=tï nï=na-ta nï ansi la-n[da] | \gls daka bilum 3SG.OBJ=be{-cond} 2SG 3SG.OBJ=TAKE 1SG=give-COND 1SG red.buai eat-IRR | \glt `If there is daka [= betel pepper] in [your] bilum [= string bag], [then] give it to me so I can chew red buai [= betel nut].’

Knowledge Point: Often context alone can determine whether a \isi{copula}r \isi{suffix} is being used in an existential construction or a \isi{locative} construction. Thus, for example, a sentence such as \REF{ex:pred:20} could be interpreted as meaning ‘the water is on the ground’ as well as ‘there is water on the ground’.
Content 1: \gsrc Inim mï ini mawat \textbf{pe}. | \gll inim mï ini ma=wat \textbf{p}-e | \gls water 3SG.SUBJ ground 3SG.OBJ=atop be{-ipfv} | \glt `There is water on the ground.’

Knowledge Point: The verb p- ‘be’ (or the \isi{copular enclitic} =p ‘\textsc{cop}’) may be used with \isi{temporal adverb}s or nouns as well, here having a \isi{temporal}, rather than a spatial meaning, as in the expression amunpe ‘still’ in \REF{ex:pred:10}. This can be understood as having the literal meaning ‘being at now’. See \sectref{sec:8.2.1} for more examples of \isi{temporal} expressions. The special \isi{past}-\isi{tense} form of the \isi{locative verb} (wap ‘be.\textsc{pst}’) is discussed in \sectref{sec:10.4}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï amunpe \textbf{andape}. | \gll mï amun=p-e \textbf{anda=p}-e | \gls 3SG.SUBJ now=COP-DEP SG.DIST=be-IPFV | \glt `He is still there.’

Knowledge Point: Aside from \isi{locational predication}, which requires the \isi{locative verb} p- {\textasciitilde} wap ‘be’, \isi{non-verbal predication} (as well as other \isi{non-verbal clause} constructions) can be expressed without any overt verbal marking. Thus, Ulwa can be said to allow \isi{zero copula} constructions (see \sectref{sec:10.3}, however, for the use of a \isi{copular enclitic}). For example, \is{classificational clause} classificational, \is{identificational clause} identificational, or \is{equational clause} equational (or \is{equative clause} equative) clauses may all be expressed by simply \isi{juxtaposing} two NPs without any marking, as in examples \REF{ex:pred:22} through \REF{ex:pred:27}. See also example \REF{ex:det:159} in \sectref{sec:7.3}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mongima mï \textbf{yata}. | \gll Mongima mï \textbf{yata} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ man | \glt `Mongima is a man.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ngata yeta mï \textbf{Suwol}. | \gll ngata yeta mï \textbf{Suwol} | \gls grand man 3SG.SUBJ [name] | \glt `The male ancestor was Suwol.’
Content 3: \gsrc Ambwat \textbf{alanji} Monde. | \gll Ambwat \textbf{ala-nji} Monde | \gls Kambot PL.DIST-POSS [name] | \glt `The Kambot people’s [ancestor] was Monde.’

Knowledge Point: Similarly, \isi{attributive clause}s (or \isi{attributional clause}s) can be formed by placing the property-denoting \isi{phrase} (i.e., the \isi{predicate adjective}) immediately after the subject NP, without any special marking, as in \REF{ex:pred:28} and \REF{ex:pred:29}.
Content 1: \gsrc Kowe mï \textbf{wutota}. | \gll Kowe mï \textbf{wutota} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ tall | \glt `Kowe is tall.’
Content 2: \gsrc Kowe mï \textbf{apka wutota}. | \gll Kowe mï \textbf{apka} \textbf{wutota} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ very tall | \glt `Kowe is very tall.’

Knowledge Point: Possessive predicates \is{possessive predication} can likewise be expressed without any marking. There is no verb like the \ili{English} verb have in Ulwa. Rather, the \isi{possessed} item is simply predicated of the person who possesses it. The \isi{possessor} is indicated by the \isi{possessive pronoun}. Thus, predicative \isi{possession} is expressed with the \isi{possessum} as the single argument of a \isi{monotransitive} clause; the \isi{possessor} is treated just like any \isi{adnominal possessor} in a possessive NP (i.e., it precedes the \isi{head noun}, \sectref{sec:9.1.5}). In examples \REF{ex:pred:30} through \REF{ex:pred:33}, the \isi{possessum} is indicated in \textbf{bold}.
Content 1: \gsrc Alimban manji \textbf{yeta watangïnila}. | \gll Alimban ma-nji \textbf{yeta} \textbf{watangïnila} | \gls [name] 3SG.OBJ-POSS man four | \glt `Alimban has four sons.’
Content 2: \gsrc Leobaha min minji \textbf{samban andawa}. | \gll Leobaha min min-nji \textbf{samban} \textbf{anda-awa} | \gls [name] 3DU 3DU-POSS pot SG.DIST{-int} | \glt `Leobaha [and another child] had their own pots.’

Knowledge Point: Although \isi{non-verbal clause}s can be formed without any overt \isi{verb phrase} (\sectref{sec:10.2}), it is also possible for a \isi{copular enclitic} =p ‘\textsc{cop}’ to be to be added to a noun, \isi{adjective}, or other \isi{parts of speech} to create a \isi{predicate}. Although clearly derived historically from the \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be at’ (< \ili{Proto-Keram} *ip), the \isi{copular enclitic} is not used for \isi{locational predication}. Rather, it is used -- always optionally -- for other kinds of \isi{non-verbal clause}s. For example, \is{classificational clause} classificational, \is{identificational clause} identificational, or \is{existential clause} existential clauses may include the \isi{clitic} =p ‘\textsc{cop}’ at the end of the second NP, as in \REF{ex:pred:34}, \REF{ex:pred:35}, and \REF{ex:pred:36}.
Content 1: \gsrc Kowe mï \textbf{atumap}. | \gll Kowe mï atuma=\textbf{p} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ older.brother=COP | \glt `Kowe is an older brother.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mï \textbf{wandampe} mï wolka molop. | \gll mï wandam-\textbf{p}-e mï wolka ma=lo-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ jungle=COP-DEP 3SG.SUBJ again 3SG.OBJ=cut{-pfv} | \glt `It was a jungle; but he cleared it again.’
Content 3: \gsrc Wondi \textbf{ulwap}. | \gll wondi ulwa=\textbf{p} | \gls bandicoot nothing=COP | \glt `There were no bandicoots.’

Knowledge Point: No \isi{tense} or \isi{aspect} distinction is made with this \isi{clitic}. However, the \isi{irrealis} \isi{suffix} -na ‘\textsc{irr}’ is generally added for \isi{irrealis} clauses, and other verbal \isi{suffix}ation may be added as well, such as the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’ in \REF{ex:pred:35}. The \isi{copular enclitic} can, in effect, function as a \isi{verbalizing} morpheme. In \REF{ex:pred:37} the \isi{irrealis} \isi{suffix} attaches to the \isi{copula}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{wandampe} mï wolka molop. | \gll mï wandam-\textbf{p}-e mï wolka ma=lo-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ jungle=COP-DEP 3SG.SUBJ again 3SG.OBJ=cut{-pfv} | \glt `It was a jungle; but he cleared it again.’
Content 2: \gsrc Kowe mï \textbf{atumapïna}. | \gll Kowe mï atuma=\textbf{p-na} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ older.brother=COP-IRR | \glt `Kowe will be an older brother.’

Knowledge Point: Likewise, \isi{attributive clause}s (or \isi{attributional clause}s) receive the \isi{copular enclitic} after the \isi{phrase} containing the property word, as illustrated by examples \REF{ex:pred:38} through \REF{ex:pred:41}.
Content 1: \gsrc Itom mï \textbf{ambip}. | \gll itom mï ambi=\textbf{p} | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ big=COP | \glt `Father is big.’
Content 2: \gsrc Un ndïlakata kuma \textbf{wapatapïta!} | \gll un ndï=la-ka-ta kuma wapata=\textbf{p-}ta | \gls 2PL 3PL=IRR-let-COND some dry=COP-COND | \glt `Let some of them dry!’

Knowledge Point: It may be possible to use the \isi{copular enclitic} to indicate \isi{possessive predication}, although I have not found any clear examples of this. Sentence \REF{ex:pred:42}, for example, may rather represent the use of the \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be’ (i.e., ‘My big one is located there.’).
Content 1: \gsrc Nïnji ambi \textbf{kwe mape}. | \gll nï-nji ambi kwe ma=\textbf{p}-e | \gls 1SG-POSS big one 3SG.OBJ=COP?-DEP | \glt `I have one big one there.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:pred:43}, which uses a \isi{nominalizing} \isi{suffix} after the \isi{copular clitic}, is perhaps better analyzed as \is{classificatory predication} classificatory or \isi{attributive predication} (i.e., ‘His land is nothing/nonexistent.’).
Content 1: \gsrc Manji ini \textbf{ulwapen}. | \gll ma-nji ini \textbf{ulwa=p-en} | \gls 3SG.OBJ-POSS ground nothing=COP-NMLZ | \glt `He doesn’t have land.’

Knowledge Point: Although the \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be’ is unmarked for \isi{tense} and, as such, may be used to refer to either \isi{past} or \isi{present} \isi{time}, there is a weakly \isi{suppletive} form wap ‘be.\textsc{pst}’, which may be used to make explicit reference to \isi{location}s in \isi{past} \isi{time}. Its use in \is{locative predication} locative predicates is illustrated by sentences \REF{ex:pred:44}, \REF{ex:pred:45}, and \REF{ex:pred:46}.
Content 1: \gsrc Amombi maka \textbf{Rabaul wap}. | \gll Amombi maka \textbf{Rabaul} \textbf{wap} | \gls [name] thus [place] be.PST | \glt `Amombi was, like, in Rabaul.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ngay mawap Ramu i \textbf{mawap}. | \gll nga=i ma=wap Ramu i \textbf{ma=wap} | \gls SG.PROX=go.PFV 3SG.OBJ=be.PST [place] go.PFV 3SG.OBJ=be.PST | \glt `[He] went there, stayed there, went to the Ramu area and stayed there.’
Content 3: \gsrc Kambaramba wa ambi maytap \textbf{mawap}. \textbf{Mawape} wusim anden pe amblasap. | \gll Kambaramba wa ambi ma=ita-p \textbf{ma=wap} \textbf{ma=wap}-e wusim anda=in p-e ambla=asa-p | \gls [place] village big 3SG.OBJ=build-PFV 3SG.OBJ=be.PST 3SG.OBJ=be.PST-DEP crocodile SG.DIST=in be{-dep} PL.REFL=hit-PFV | \glt `[They] built the big village Kambaramba and stayed there. While staying there, they fought one another over the crocodile.’

Knowledge Point: As with the form p- ‘be’, the use of the form wap ‘be.\textsc{pst}’ may at times be ambiguous between \isi{locative predication} and \isi{existential predication}, as in \REF{ex:pred:47} and \REF{ex:pred:48}.
Content 1: \gsrc Anmoka mï apa \textbf{mawap} i. | \gll anmoka mï apa \textbf{ma=wap} i | \gls snake 3SG.SUBJ house 3SG.OBJ=be.PST go.PFV | \glt `There was a snake in the house, [but it] left.’
Content 2: \gsrc Inim mï awal ini mawat \textbf{wap}. | \gll inim mï awal ini ma=wat \textbf{wap} | \gls water 3SG.SUBJ yesterday ground 3SG.OBJ=atop be.PST | \glt `There was water on the ground yesterday.’

Knowledge Point: It is perhaps possible for the \isi{past}-\isi{tense} \isi{locative verb} form wap ‘be.\textsc{pst}’ to be used as a \isi{copula}r verb (i.e., for non-\isi{locative predication}, such as \is{classificatory predication} classificatory, \is{equative predication} equative, or \isi{attributive predication}), but the only examples of this that I have seen come from targeted elicitation and may not be representative of traditional or naturalistic speech. Sentences \REF{ex:pred:49}, \REF{ex:pred:50}, and \REF{ex:pred:51} provide examples of \isi{copula}r uses of wap ‘be.\textsc{pst’}.
Content 1: \gsrc Kowe mï \textbf{atuma wap}. | \gll Kowe mï atuma \textbf{wap} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ older.brother be.PST | \glt `Kowe was an older brother.’
Content 2: \gsrc Itom mï \textbf{ambi wap}. | \gll itom mï ambi \textbf{wap} | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ big be.PST | \glt `Father was big.’
Content 3: \gsrc Banjiwa mï \textbf{ankam anma wap} amun tembip. | \gll Banjiwa mï ankam anma \textbf{wap} amun tembi=p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ person good be.PST now bad=COP | \glt `Banjiwa was a good person, but now he is bad.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{imperfective} or \isi{irrealis} form of ma- ‘go’ may be used as an \isi{auxiliary verb} along with an \isi{irrealis} form of a main verb to signal the \isi{future}, nearly paralleling the \ili{English} \isi{periphrastic} \isi{future} construction with going to and an \isi{infinitive}. These Ulwa \isi{future} constructions are illustrated in examples \REF{ex:pred:52} through \REF{ex:pred:56}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï ma na \textbf{tana man}. | \gll nï ma na \textbf{ta-na} \textbf{ma-n} | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ talk say-IRR go-IPFV | \glt `I am going to tell its story.’
Content 2: \gsrc Apwanam ita wa \textbf{mapïna mane}. | \gll apwanam i-ta wa ma=\textbf{p-na} \textbf{ma-n-e} | \gls side.of.house go.PFV-COND just 3SG.OBJ=be-IRR go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `If [you] go to the side of the house, [you] are just going to stay there.’

Knowledge Point: Examples such as \REF{ex:pred:55} and \REF{ex:pred:56}, in which the main verb is the static \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be’, illustrate the purely \isi{temporal} or \isi{modal} use of this verb ma- ‘go’ -- that is, a use without any sense of \isi{motion}. While the \isi{imperfective} form of ma- ‘go’ is most often used in these constructions, it is alternatively possible to use an \isi{irrealis} (or even \isi{conditional}) form of the verb, as shown by \REF{ex:pred:57} and \REF{ex:pred:58}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï men \textbf{pïna mane}. | \gll ndï ma=in \textbf{p-na} \textbf{ma-n-e} | \gls 3PL 3SG.OBJ=in be-IRR go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `They are going to stay inside it.’
Content 2: \gsrc Apwanam ita wa \textbf{mapïna mane}. | \gll apwanam i-ta wa ma=\textbf{p-na} \textbf{ma-n-e} | \gls side.of.house go.PFV-COND just 3SG.OBJ=be-IRR go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `If [you] go to the side of the house, [you] are just going to stay there.’
Content 3: \gsrc U angos \textbf{tïna mana}? | \gll u angos \textbf{tï-na} \textbf{ma-na} | \gls 2SG what take-IRR go-IRR | \glt `What could you be going to get?’
Content 4: \gsrc Una tïmbïl men \textbf{pïta manata} … | \gll unan tïmbïl ma=in \textbf{p-ta} \textbf{ma-na-ta} | \gls 1PL.INCL fence 3SG.OBJ=in be{-cond} go-IRR-COND | \glt `If we are going to be within the fence …’

Knowledge Point: While it is theoretically possible that \isi{perfective} forms of the verb may be used in such constructions as well (i.e., the \isi{suppletive} form i ‘go.\textsc{pfv’}), I do not have clear examples of this. Some apparent examples of \isi{periphrastic} \isi{future} constructions with i ‘go.\textsc{pfv}’ are in fact constructions with \isi{purpose clause}s, which also contain \isi{irrealis} verb forms. For example, sentences \REF{ex:pred:59} and \REF{ex:pred:60} are not analyzed as \isi{periphrastic} \isi{future} constructions, but rather as \isi{purpose} constructions.
Content 1: \gsrc Ala \textbf{unanwalinda i}. | \gll ala \textbf{unan=wali-nda} \textbf{i} | \gls PL.DIST 1PL.INCL=hit-IRR go.PFV | \glt `Those people have come to fight us.’
Content 2: \gsrc Min tïlwanï wandam \textbf{kolnda iye}. | \gll min tïlwa=nï wandam \textbf{kol-nda} \textbf{i}-e | \gls 3DU road=OBL jungle split-IRR go.PFV-DEP | \glt `The two went to split the jungle from the path.’

Knowledge Point: Indeed, it is often difficult to determine whether a ‘going’ verb is marking futurity or \isi{purpose}. This is perhaps unsurprising, if one assumes the likely historical change of: verb of \isi{motion} > \isi{purpose} > \isi{future}. In examples \REF{ex:pred:61} and \REF{ex:pred:62}, the \ili{English} translations capture the ambiguity well. In \REF{ex:pred:61}, a reading in which the ‘going’ verb marks futurity would suggest that the first clause is \isi{counterfactual}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï apïn anul \textbf{landa mane} mï ipka i. | \gll ndï apïn=n anul \textbf{la-nda} \textbf{ma-n}-e mï ipka i | \gls 3PL fire=OBL grassland eat-IRR go-IPFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ before go.PFV | \glt `They were going to burn the grassland, but he went ahead [of them].’
Content 2: \gsrc Magendo lol \textbf{amblawalinda mane}. | \gll Magendo ala=ul \textbf{ambla=wali-nda} \textbf{ma-n}-e | \gls [place] PL.DIST=with PL.REFL=hit-IRR go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `[They] were going to fight with the people from Magendo [village].’
Content 3: \gsrc Ndï apïn anul \textbf{landa mane} mï ipka i. | \gll ndï apïn=n anul \textbf{la-nda} \textbf{ma-n}-e mï ipka i | \gls 3PL fire=OBL grassland eat-IRR go-IPFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ before go.PFV | \glt `They were going to burn the grassland, but he went ahead [of them].’

Knowledge Point: Whereas only ma- ‘go’ seems to be permitted in \isi{periphrastic} \isi{future} constructions, it is possible for other \isi{motion} verbs to indicate \isi{purpose} as well, such as the verb lo- ‘cut, go’ and in- ‘come’, as seen in \REF{ex:pred:63} and \REF{ex:pred:64}.\footnote{It should be noted, however, that the exact \isi{syntactic} nature of these \isi{purpose} constructions is not entirely clear. It seems that only \isi{motion} verbs permit this \isi{embedded clause} structure to express \isi{purpose}. Elsewhere, the clause indicating \isi{purpose} simply follows the clause detailing the action performed for that \isi{purpose} (see \sectref{sec:4.6}).}
Content 1: \gsrc Wongïta man \textbf{matïna lope}. | \gll wongïta ma=n \textbf{ma=atï-na} \textbf{lo-p}-e | \gls bow 3SG.OBJ=OBL 3SG.OBJ=take-IRR go-PFV-DEP | \glt `[I] went to hit it with [my] bow.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndït \textbf{ndïnanda} ndïnap \textbf{ine}. | \gll ndï=tï \textbf{ndï=na-nda} ndï=nap \textbf{i-n}-e | \gls 3PL=take 3PL=give-IRR 3PL=for come-PFV-DEP | \glt `[They] came for their sake to give them [= fish] to them [= their people].’
